In this study we investigated, theoretically and experimentally, the unique photoactive behavior of pristine and defected indium oxide surfaces providing fundamental insights into their excited state properties as well as an explanation for the experimentally observed enhanced activity of defected indium oxide surfaces for the gas-phase reverse water gas shift reaction, CO 2 H 2 h CO H 2 O in the light compared to the dark.To this end, a detailed excited-state study of pristine and defected forms of indium

which contribute significantly to each excitation similar to the case of the pristine surface.This favors easy electron transport on the These charge analyses also show that the substantial OH character is present in the HOMO of In 2 O 3-x (OH) y but is absent in the LUMO.This means that in the presence of light, electrons are transferred from OH to In for the less intense, S0 S1 transition.In other words, if we consider OH groups behaving as ligands, charge transfer on the In 2 O 3-x (OH) y surface has

unsaturated surface In atom.Thus, as illustrated in Figure 7, in the presence of light, the In 2 O 3-x (OH) y surface becomes photoactive due to charge delocalization that enhances the Lewis acidic and Lewis basic character of InInOH surface FLPs.This highly active excited state FLP surface destabilizes the reactant state and raises its total energy, which could explain the experimentally observed decrease in the activation barrier of CO 2 reduction by 20 kJ mol -1 in the light compared to the dark. 10
